newsitem.title: GERMANY: French vote prompts calls for change in Germany.
newsitem.headline: French vote prompts calls for change in Germany.

text.p: The French left's election win, coming one month after Labour's victory in Britain, prompted calls in Germany on Monday for the centre-right government to ease its austerity drive and do more to fight unemployment.

Even allies of Chancellor Helmut Kohl said the second left-wing victory in a major European country was a warning to Bonn to end its bickering and view Europe's monetary union (EMU) as more than just an issue of meeting strict targets.

An ally of Finance Minister Theo Waigel, speaking about a row over revaluing gold reserves for EMU, also backed delaying the start of the single currency in 1999 if Germany could not meet the three percent deficit-to-GDP Maastricht target.
The opposition Social Democrats (SPD) hailed Lionel Jospin's victory in the French parliamentary election as the latest wave in a tide of left-wing sentiment in Europe.
German politicians were split over whether a Socialist government in Paris would continue to support EMU or cave in to communist pressure and delay the euro's launch.

But all saw the change in Bonn's closest partner as a factor in a changing political scene in Germany, where the row over Bundesbank gold has already raised the prospect of cracks in the hitherto solid support in the political elite for Kohl's iron-willed pro-Europeanism at almost any cost.
Rainer Eppelmann, head of the CDA trade union wing of Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU), said the government had to heed the lesson of the French poll.

"The next German general election will be decided on the issues of social justice and fighting unemployment," he said, referring to the September 1998 vote in which Kohl wants to be reelected to ensure he can see EMU launched.
